qas.question: What is the origin of the word ale?
What is the origin of the word beer?
What word means to drink in Latin?
What 12th century poet once wrote "Ale it is called among men, but among the gods, beer."?
What is the plural of the word ale?
What does the word alu hold connotations of?

plausible_answers.text: "Ale it is called among men, but among the gods, beer."

qas.question: What does the 12th-Century Old Germanic poem Alvissmal say?
What is the Latin word for barley?

context: The word ale comes from <a0_0>Old English ealu<a0_0/> (plural <b4_0>ealoþ<b4_0/>), in turn from Proto-Germanic *alu (plural *aluþ), ultimately from the Proto-Indo-European base *h₂elut-, which holds connotations of "<b5_0>sorcery, magic, possession, intoxication<b5_0/>". The word beer comes from <a1_0>Old English bēor<a1_0/>, from Proto-Germanic *beuzą, probably from Proto-Indo-European *bʰeusóm, originally "brewer's yeast, beer dregs", although other theories have been provided connecting the word with Old English bēow, "barley", or Latin <a2_0><b7_0>bibere<b7_0/><a2_0/>, "to drink". On the currency of two words for the same thing in the Germanic languages, the 12th-century Old Icelandic poem <a3_0>Alvíssmál<a3_0/> says, <b6_0>"Ale it is called among men, but among the gods, beer."
